page.title: 01Hills Northeast of Ludlow
page.content: This is a section of escarpment, lowest in the Northwest, just below 170m in the Corvedale valley and highest in East on the summit of Brown Clee Hill,Abdon Burf, 540m above sea level, the highest point in the county. Just below the top, between aout 470m and 500m, there is a short plateau of rough grass, sedge,moss,heather and gorse with bracken clothing the steeper slopes to bout the 340m level. Some former quarry/mining buildings remain. At this height, a lane circumvents brown Clee to North and west,and along it are the highest farms with their inroadsd of better pasture. Elsewhere are dispersed farms,cottages and a few modern houses in quiet spots with panoramic views. Much of the older original buildings is of hustone, a brown black,basall rock which capped
